Clark |Ship christened= |Ship completed= |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 6 July 1985 |Ship recommissioned= |Ship decommissioned=2 November 2007<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nvr.navy.mil/nvrships/details/SSN718.htm |title=HONOLULU (SSN 718)}}</ref> |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=[[Puget Sound Naval Shipyard]] |Ship identification= |Ship motto= ''Maka `Ala Mau'' ([[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]] for "Always On Alert") |Ship nickname= |Ship honors= |Ship captured= |Ship fate= [[Ship-Submarine recycling program|Disposed of by submarine recycling]] |Ship status= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= [[Image:SSN718crest.gif|200px]] }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= [[Los Angeles class submarine]] |Ship type= |Ship tonnage= |Ship displacement= 5,700 tons light, 6,068 tons full, 368 tons dead |Ship length= {{convert|110.3|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship height= |Ship draft= {{convert|9.4|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship depth= |Ship decks= |Ship power= |Ship propulsion=[[S6G reactor|S6G nuclear reactor]] |Ship speed= |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship test depth= |Ship complement=12 officers, 98 men |Ship time to activate= |Ship sensors= |Ship EW= |Ship armament= 4 Ã 21 in (533 mm) torpedo tubes |Ship armor= |Ship notes= }} |} {{otherships|USS Honolulu}} '''USS ''Honolulu'' (SSN-718)''', was a [[Los Angeles class submarine|''Los Angeles''-class submarine]], was the third ship of the [[United States Navy]] to be named for [[Honolulu, Hawaii]]. The contract to build her was awarded to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]] on 15 September 1977 and her keel was laid down on 10 November 1981. She was [[ship naming and launching|launched]] on 24 September 1983 sponsored by Mrs. Joan B. Clark, and [[ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 6 July 1985, with Commander Robert M. Mitchell in command.
[[Image:Polar bears near north pole.jpg|300px|left|thumb|Three [[polar bear]]s approach ''Honolulu''{{'}}s [[starboard]] [[Bow (ship)|bow]] while she is on the surface 280 nautical miles (519 kilometers) from the [[North Pole]].]]''Honolulu'' featured unique split stern planes that operated from independent hydraulic systems. With this redundant configuration, the inboard and outboard planes could be operated independently, preventing a failure of one or the other from causing an uncontrolled dive.
''Honolulu''âs patrols are commemorated by ten [[surfboard]]s signed by the crews aboard her at the time. The latest three are kept on board the submarine; the other seven are stored at [[Pearl Harbor]].
''Honolulu'' held a farewell ceremony in Pearl Harbor on 15 April, 2006, that included remarks by Senator [[Daniel K. Inouye]], Lieutenant Governor [[James Aiona]], U.S. Pacific Fleet commander Admiral [[Gary Roughead]] and former ''Honolulu'' commanding officer Vice Admiral [[Jonathan Greenert]]. ''Honolulu'' put to sea in early May 2006 for her final patrol. Her last patrol ended at [[Puget Sound Naval Shipyard]] in October 2006 where she was placed on stand down, on her way to decommissioning.
==Final Deposition== ''Honolulu'' was [[Ship decommissioning|decommissioned]] and stricken from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] on 2 November 2007. Ex-''Honolulu'' entered the [[Nuclear Powered Ship and Submarine Recycling Program]] in [[Bremerton, Washington]].
The forward section of ex-''Honolulu'' was transferred to [[USS San Francisco (SSN-711)|USS ''San Francisco'' (SSN-711)]], repairing extensive damage caused by a severe grounding ''San Francisco'' experienced in 2005. The "challenging, one-of-a-kind project" was completed on 20 October 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=40390 |title=USS San Francisco Undocks With New Bow |date=2008-10-20}}</ref>
